misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that `Scanner.next()` will read an entire student name as a full String (potentially including spaces), matching the prompt "Enter names".
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `Scanner.next()` reads only the next whitespace-delimited token. If a student name can contain spaces (e.g., "Mary Jane"), `next()` will split it into multiple inputs and shift the remaining reads, causing later names/scores to be read into the wrong array positions. To read full names with spaces, the program would need `nextLine()` with careful newline handling.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong data mapping between `names` and `scores` (misaligned arrays), leading to incorrect sorting/output, or input being "consumed" unexpectedly.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Assuming Non-Empty Arrays When Taking “Last Element”
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes it is always valid to compute `numberOfStudents - 1` and use it as an array index to access the "top student".
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: If `numberOfStudents` can be 0, then `indexOfTopStudent` becomes -1, and accessing `studentNames[-1]` / `studentScores[-1]` will throw `ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException`. Java arrays require indices in `[0, length-1]`. A guard is needed for the `N == 0` case if the input constraints do not guarantee `N >= 1`.
